channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Global Leaders Pledge to End Deforestation by 2030
item.description: The measure reflects a growing recognition of nature’s role in helping mitigate global warming.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Chris Buckley
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Deforestation next to a palm oil plantation after fires in South Kalimantan Province, Indonesia, in 2019. Land clearing is a major source of carbon dioxide, the main gas causing global warming.

item.title: Men in Gaza Imprisoned Over Wedding Loans
item.description: Like many men in Gaza, Wasfi al-Garosha regularly returns to prison for failing to repay a wedding loan. His trip back, always on foot, reveals much about the stresses of life in the Strip.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wasfi al-Garosha with his wife and daughter on the morning he returned to jail in Gaza City.

item.title: After Violent Standoff, Pakistan Strikes Deal With Banned Islamist Group
item.description: The pact, announced Sunday, defused a crisis that had paralyzed several cities, but it also highlighted the government’s struggle to assert itself against religious extremists.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Supporters of the banned Islamist group Tehreek-e-Labaik marched toward Islamabad, Pakistan’s capital, from Lahore on Oct. 23.

item.title: Egypt Poised to Expand Security Powers of President and Military
item.description: Amendments to a terrorism law will strengthen the grip of the government, just days after it appeared to loosen up by lifting a state of emergency.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt last month in Hungary.

item.title: Nigeria Building Collapse Kills at Least 5 With Many More Trapped
item.description: As many as 100 workers were feared trapped at a construction site in Lagos, where building collapses are common, with contractors using shoddy materials and regulations often not enforced.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Ismail Alfa
item.media:description: The police and rescue workers at the construction site of a 21-story apartment building that collapsed in Lagos, Nigeria, on Monday.

item.title: New Zealand Held a Bird Contest. A Bat Won.
item.description: The long-tailed bat, one of the country’s only two native land mammals, flew away with the top prize.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: He Brokered Apartheid’s End. Can He Save South Africa’s Liberation Party?
item.description: President Cyril Ramaphosa ascended to office on a reputation as a great negotiator and consensus builder. Now he must persuade voters to stick with the party of Nelson Mandela.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa campaigning on Friday in Sebokeng, south of Johannesburg, for candidates with his African National Congress who are contending in nationwide local elections on Monday.

item.title: U.K. Police Struggle to Curb Abuse of Women by Their Own Officers
item.description: Sexual misconduct by police officers has prompted outrage across Britain and led to increasing skepticism that departments can investigate or discipline employees who abuse women.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: British police are under increasing scrutiny for instances of sexual misconduct by officers.

item.title: At COP26 Summit, Urgent Pleas to Combat Global Warning
item.description: The opening day of a climate summit was heavy on dire warnings and light on substantive proposals as leaders in Glasgow met to discuss a warming world.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, Lisa Friedman and Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Screens relaying live feeds of the opening ceremony in the media hub of climate summit in Glasgow on Monday.

item.title: Fossil Fuel Spending Far Outstrips COP26's Funding for Forests
item.description: As the world stares down the barrel of climate catastrophe and a worsening biodiversity crisis, the forests that are remain are crucial.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rainforest peatlands, like this one in Indonesia, have been increasingly cleared to make way for palm oil plantations in recent decades. That releases the greenhouse gases they used to trap.

item.title: Ecuador Vows at COP26 to Create Marine Reserve for Galápagos Islands
item.description: President Guillermo Lasso said his government had agreed with Ecuador’s fishery, tourism and conservation sectors to establish a marine reserve of more than 23,000 square miles.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Nicholas Casey
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Sea lions in a bay on Isabela Island in the Galapagos.

item.title: Dozens Killed in Attack on Military Hospital in Afghanistan’s Capital
item.description: No group has claimed responsibility for the violence, but the Islamic State has struck more often since the fall of the U.S.-backed government in August.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Sami Sahak
item.media:description: A boy injured during an attack targeting a military hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Jeff Bezos Makes $2 Billion Environmental Pledge at COP26 Summit
item.description: The billionaire called the loss of Earth’s forests “a profound and urgent danger to us all.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Nicholas Kulish
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos said at the Glasgow conference that Amazon aimed to power all of its operations by renewable energies by 2025.

item.title: China Urges Families to Stock up on Food for Winter
item.description: State-run news media said that the directives were to prepare for emergencies like coronavirus lockdowns as the country pursues its “zero Covid” policy.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: People lining up to weigh groceries in a supermarket in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Pledges $3 Billion to Help the World Adapt to Climate Change
item.description: The amount is half as much as what was recently proposed for a six-mile sea wall to protect Miami from the Atlantic Ocean.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: President Biden speaking on Tuesday during the COP26 summit in Glasgow.

item.title: Britain's Covid Response Offers a Warning to Other Countries
item.description: Britain offers a warning of what happens when a country ignores Covid.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Claire Moses
item.media:description: A crowd in London at a screening of Dune last month.

item.title: China Makes It a Crime to Mock Country's Heroes
item.description: Under a new law, China has zealously prosecuted even the perceived slander of Communist figures, broadening Xi Jinping’s campaign to dominate party orthodoxy.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A painting showing Mao with Red Army soldiers and officers at the National Art Museum in Beijing during the exhibition “100 Years Toward Greatness” in June.

item.title: Reduce fossil fuels in the long term but pump more now, Biden says, angering activists.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: President Biden with John Kerry, the U.S. climate envoy, during the opening session of the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Glasgow on Monday.

item.title: Day 2 of the climate summit brings the first concrete commitments.
item.description: The U.S. is expected to announce plans to regulate methane, a potent greenhouse gas, and there is international agreement to tackle deforestation.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel, left, with President Biden and Prime Minister Boris Johnson at an evening reception at the COP26 conference in Glasgow.

item.title: As Earth Warms, Human History Is Melting Away
item.description: Climate change is revealing long-frozen artifacts and animals to archaeologists. But the window for study is slender and shrinking.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.media:credit: Glacier Archaeology Program, Innlandet County Council
item.media:description: The Langfonne ice patch in Norway.

item.title: How Car Shortages Are Putting the Economy at Risk
item.description: Because so many jobs depend on automaking, the industry’s production problems are causing the pain to ripple.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing and Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Opel factory in Eisenach, Germany, is halting production and doesn’t plan to restart until next year.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Old divides at a major climate summit.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden urged countries to cooperate in the fight against climate change during the opening day of the summit.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Urges Climate Action in COP26 Video
item.description: The 95-year-old monarch gave her address by video, after doctors advised her to rest and not go to the summit. Prince Charles attended and delivered a similar message.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A reception in Glasgow on Monday where attendees, including members of the royal family, top right, watched the queen’s video message.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Leaders forcefully call for action at COP26.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: President Joe Biden attends the opening session of the COP26 conference in Glasgow on Monday.

item.title: India Will Sharply Increase Renewable Energy, Modi Says
item.description: Wealthy nations need to spend $1 trillion to help developing nations like India make the transition to renewables, Prime Minister Modi said.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A shepherd amid solar panels in Kyataganacharulu, a village in Karnataka State, India, last month.

item.title: From the Amazon to Glasgow: An Indigenous activist says, ‘We have no more time.’
item.description: Txai Suruí told world leaders at COP26 that their timetables for reducing carbon emissions and scaling back the use of fossil fuels were inadequate.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Txai Suruí, an indigenous activist from Brazil, at the U.N. climate conference in Glasgow.

item.title: Biden Calls for Tougher Actions on Emissions at COP26
item.description: “We have only a brief window” to avoid the most disastrous effects of global warming, President Biden warned at the United Nations climate summit.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: President Biden attending the opening session.

item.title: Global Covid Death Toll Surpasses 5 Million, but Full Count Is Higher
item.description: Many countries do not accurately report their figures, and many Covid deaths are misattributed, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Relatives attended a funeral for a man who died from the coronavirus in Valle de Chalco, Mexico, last month.

item.title: David Attenborough Urges Leaders at COP26 Summit to ‘Rewrite Our Story’
item.description: “If working apart we are force powerful enough to destabilize our planet,” the naturalist said, “surely working together we are powerful enough to save it.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: David Attenborough at the premiere of “Green Planet” as COP26 arrived in Glasgow on Sunday.

item.title: Handball Federation Ends Bikini Bottom Requirement for Women
item.description: After outrage over a fine levied against the Norwegian women’s beach handball team for competing in shorts, the sport’s international federation said it was changing its rules.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: The Norway women’s beach handball team in 2018. The team said the rule requiring them to play in bikini bottoms was sexist.

item.title: U.N. Leader, António Guterres, Warns of 'Climate Catastrophe' at COP26
item.description: He urged countries to review their climate pledges annually rather than every five years as called for in the 2015 Paris accord.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, left, and U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres preparing to receive attendees at the U.N. Climate Change Conference on Monday in Glasgow, Scotland.

item.title: Thailand Reopens to Tourists Without Requiring Quarantine
item.description: About a fifth of the nation’s economy depends on the vacation industry. Before the pandemic, the country was one of the world’s top destinations, drawing nearly 40 million visitors in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Organizing health screening and document checks on Monday at Suvarnabhumi Airport, which serves Bangkok.

item.title: China’s push to burn more coal puts climate goals at risk.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal warehouse in Shanxi Province, China.

item.title: How to Prevent Climate Disasters
item.description: World leaders are in Glasgow.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ivanpah solar power facility in the Mojave Desert.

item.title: John Kerry Plays Down COP26 Expectations
item.description: “Glasgow was never ever going to get every country joining up,” Mr. Kerry said. He’s already looking to next year to build on pledges that nations have made and push them to do more.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: John Kerry, the U.S. climate envoy, second left, at the U.N. General Assembly in September. “It is critical that countries lay out better plans” on climate, he said on Sunday.

item.title: Who Is Attending the COP26 Climate Summit, and Who Isn't
item.description: The presence of heads of state and government is not just symbolic. Real work gets done among leaders that cannot happen among lower-level diplomats.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski, Carlotta Gall and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin of Russia attended an energy conference in Moscow in October and said there that he would not attend the climate summit in Glasgow.

item.title: Greta Thunberg Arrives in Glasgow for COP26 and Joins a Protest
item.description: The activist, whose solo climate strikes in 2018 helped fuel a youth climate movement, was greeted like a rock star upon arriving in the city, according to videos.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Marc Santora
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Greta Thunberg arriving at a train station in Glasgow on Saturday.

item.title: The Stunning Grandeur of Soviet-Era Metros
item.description: Between 2014 and 2020, Frank Herfort visited more than 770 metro stations in 19 cities, creating a remarkable archive of architectural and artistic splendor.
item.dc:creator: Frank Herfort

item.title: Biden’s Glasgow pitch: This time, the U.S. is serious about climate change.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Jim Tankersley and Coral Davenport
item.media:description: President Biden at the end of the Group of 20 summit in Rome on Sunday.

item.title: What to Watch For At COP26 on Monday and Tuesday
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson was first to welcome leaders, who will then lay out “concrete actions and credible plans.” David Attenborough and Prince Charles are also speaking.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez and Ethan Hauser
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain arriving for COP26 in Glasgow on Monday.

item.title: Climate conference kicks off in Glasgow with floods and low expectations.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the main entrance of the COP26 summit in Glasgow on Monday.

item.title: Michael Bloomberg announces an effort to shut down coal in 25 countries.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael R. Bloomberg in New York in September. “Coal is enemy No. 1 in the battle over climate change,” he said in a statement.

item.title: Australia Allows Residents, Citizens to Return as Borders Open
item.description: After 18 months of strict measures to combat the pandemic, the states of New South Wales and Victoria relaxed restrictions on citizens and permanent residents seeking to travel back from overseas.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang, Niki Kitsantonis, Richard C. Paddock, Muktita Suhartono and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: An airport in Melbourne, Australia, on Monday. Tens of thousands of Australians have been stranded overseas by the stringent border measures imposed to combat the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Once a Leading Polluter, the U.K. Is Now Trying to Lead on Climate Change
item.description: On the eve of a global climate summit, Britain’s evolution from fossil fuels to clean energy is on display. But experts question whether its commitment is sufficient, and whether it can persuade other nations to meet meaningful goals.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Black Law Wind Farm in Lanark, Scotland. Britain’s high-tech windmills and superannuated smokestacks are the most visible evidence of a three-decade campaign

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Deciding the future of the climate.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters held a procession on Sunday through Glasgow ahead of COP26 to highlight the climate crisis.

item.title: Struggling at Home, Biden Is Buoyed by G20 Trip Abroad
item.description: A trip to Rome invigorated a president whose poll numbers are slumping at home, but who projected confidence in his foreign and domestic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Katie Rogers
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: President Biden at the end of the Group of 20 summit in Rome.

item.title: Brazilian Police Kill 25 Accused of Planning Bank Heists
item.description: The police say an operation against a gang planning bank robberies killed at least 25 suspects in the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: At Climate Talks, Biden Will Try to Sell American Leadership to Skeptics
item.description: The president wants to assure Glasgow’s climate summit that the U.S. is serious about climate change. But he lacks a legislative win at home.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Jim Tankersley and Coral Davenport
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: President Biden at the French Embassy in Rome on Friday, before heading to Scotland to attend the U.N. climate change conference, or COP26, in Glasgow.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Climate conference begins in Glasgow.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters held a procession through Glasgow ahead of COP26 on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. Military Jury Condemns Terrorist’s Torture and Urges Clemency
item.description: Seven senior officers rebuked the government’s treatment of an admitted terrorist in a handwritten letter from the jury room at Guantánamo Bay.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Over 2,000 New York City Firefighters Took Sick Days as Vaccine Mandate Looms
item.description: More than 22,000 municipal workers remained unvaccinated a day before a city deadline to get their first dose of a coronavirus vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein and Ashley Southall
item.media:description: When the vaccine mandate goes into effect Monday, unvaccinated municipal employees without a religious or medical exemption, including firefighters, will be placed on unpaid leave.

item.title: F.D.A. Is Reviewing If Moderna Vaccine Causes Heart Problems in Adolescents
item.description: The F.D.A. has notified Moderna that it needs more time to review the vaccine’s safety and may not deliver a decision until January.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Several European countries have paused use of the Moderna vaccine in young people, citing concerns about myocarditis — an inflammation of the heart muscle.

item.title: G20 Nations Agree to New Limits on Coal-Burning Power Plants
item.description: The world’s largest economies will stop financing coal plants abroad, though that falls far short of what’s needed to fight climate change, raising fears of half-steps at this week’s U.N. summit.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta, Jason Horowitz and Jim Tankersley
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Coal moving to barges for transport in Belle, W.Va.
